title: 112_hr6040
content: The Act titled "Continued Free Association with Palau Act of 2012" is cited as the official name. It amends Title I of Public Law 99-658 by adding a section for the 15th-anniversary review agreement. The Agreement between the United States and the Republic of Palau, signed in 2010, is approved with exceptions and subject to certain provisions. Funding provisions for infrastructure maintenance in fiscal year 2011 are outlined. Funding provisions for infrastructure maintenance, fiscal consolidation fund, and infrastructure projects between the United States and Palau are outlined for fiscal years 2011 through 2017. The United States will provide funding under the Agreement in fiscal years 2011 through 2016, to be provided in fiscal years 2012 through 2017. Congress consents to amendments to the Compact subsidiary agreements. A law amendment extends the application until 2024. Authorization of appropriations for postal services related to Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands is set at $1,500,000 for each fiscal year from 2012 to 2024. The Department of the Interior may transfer funds to the United States Postal Service for mail to Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands. Appropriations for Federal entities under the Compact of Free Association may continue through fiscal year 2024. The Department of the Interior can transfer funds to the United States Postal Service for mail to Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands. Appropriations for Federal entities under the Compact of Free Association may continue through fiscal year 2024. The United States commitments under the Compact Review Agreement are subject to full faith and credit, with oversight and reporting to appropriate Congressional committees. The Secretary of the Interior must submit an annual report to specific Senate and House committees by March 1 each year regarding the financial assistance provided to Palau under U.S. domestic programs. The report should detail the use and effectiveness of the assistance. The Secretary of the Interior must consult with the relevant Federal agency or agencies regarding domestic programs. SEC. 3. OFFSETS. Repeal of prior authorization for civil administration of Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands and limitation on use of funds for global health programs under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. SEC. 136. LIMITATION ON USE OF FUNDS. None of the funds for global health activities from fiscal year 2012 to 2024 can be used for assistance to China. The total amount for global health activities is reduced by $2,000,000 each fiscal year. This section applies regardless of any other laws enacted later. None of the funds for climate change activities from fiscal year 2012 to 2024 can be used to assist China. The total amount for these activities is reduced by $4,500,000 each fiscal year. This restriction applies despite any future laws enacted. Additionally, funding for the Development Innovation Ventures (DIV) Program is prohibited for fiscal years 2012 onwards. The U.S. Agency for International Development is restricted from using funds for the Development Innovation Ventures (DIV) program or any successor program for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. The total amount available for the Agency for a fiscal year is reduced by $28,200,000. Additionally, the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to limit the use of funds for IMET activities. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to restrict funds for assistance to Argentina from fiscal year 2012 through 2024. Additionally, the Act limits the total amount available for certain activities by $4,500,000 annually. SEC. 308. LIMITATION ON USE OF FUNDS. SEC. 308. LIMITATION ON USE OF FUNDS. None of the funds for US contributions to the UN can be used for UNESCO. The total amount for UN contributions is reduced by $4,500,000 annually. This applies regardless of other laws. United States Institute of Peace funding is also limited. The United States Institute of Peace funding is limited to $6,811,000 less than the total amount available for fiscal years 2012 through 2024, regardless of other laws enacted after this provision.
